But what exactly can the players find? 21st century chain grocery stores are filled with a boggling array of possible things that the characters might want and need. This list, along with past and more lists to come, helps to provide the GM a random chart solution to handling the diverse loot of such places.

- Publisher's description

208478.name: Apocalypse 100: Grocery Store Loot 4
208478.description:
The characters are exploring a commercial district of the devastated city and they come across a grocery supermarket grocery store. Although the place has seen its share of looting there is still quite a bit to be found scattered amongst the debris and overturned shelves and carts. But what exactly can the players find? 21st century chain grocery stores are filled with a boggling array of possible things that the characters might want and need. This list, along with past and more lists to come, helps to provide the GM a random chart solution to handling the diverse loot of such places.

- Publisher's description

208479.name: Apocalypse 100: Grocery Store Loot 5
208479.description:
The characters are exploring a commercial district of the devastated city and they come across a grocery supermarket grocery store. Although the place has seen its share of looting there is still quite a bit to be found scattered amongst the debris and overturned shelves and carts. But what exactly can the players find? 21st century chain grocery stores are filled with a boggling array of possible things that the characters might want and need. This list, along with past and more lists to come, helps to provide the GM a random chart solution to handling the diverse loot of such places.

- Publisher's description

208480.description:
Wordsy is a streamlined re-implementation of Prolix, a word game from 2010.

Each round, players study the 8 letters (always consonants) on the board in real time. The first player to write down a word flips a 30-second timer. That player is now the fastest player, and every other player now has 30 seconds to write down their word.

Once time has run out, the fastest player scores their word by counting the point value of each of the matching letters on the board. Players are not limited to the letters on the board; they can add any letters they'd like. Letters score based on which of the 4 columns of the board they're in, and how rare they are.

After the fastest player scores, the first player clockwise scores their word, and compares it to the fastest player. If that player scored more than the fastest player, they score a small bonus.

Every other player scores their word and checks for a bonus. Once they've all done this, the fastest player scores a bonus if their score is equal to or higher than half the other player's scores.

After 7 rounds, players add the scores their best 5 words, plus their bonuses. The player with the most points wins!
208480.name: Wordsy
boardgamepodcastepisode: #33: Captain Sonar on tap; Extra Life & MACE gaming weekends
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 99

208481.name: Bigtyme Football
208481.description: A combination sports and gambling game where each player plays as a team owner, competes through an entire season, and attempts to make the most money. As the sales sheet states, "Follow the season schedule and win or lose millions playing football games against your friends. Your luck will also be tested by picking Safe or Risk cards when you are the Home Team."

208482.name: Dragon Kings
208482.description:
Dragon Kings is a deck building game consisting of 55 cards. In Dragon Kings, players develop a deck by using mana to purchase and cast new Spells/Dragons from the Dragon Pit. The Dragon Pit is the set of powerful neutral cards that belong to neither player, placed in the center of the play area. With the aid of the Dragons and Spells purchased from the Dragon Pit, the players' ultimate goal is to reduce their opponent's life to 0.

Dragons Kings is a 2-player game (or 4 players with 2 decks) that introduces players to deck building.

208484.name: Vampire Hunter$ (OGL-Compatible Edition)
208484.description:
From the introduction:

Vampires exist.

Vampires stalk our cities, finding nourishment in the crimson lifeblood of an unwitting and helpless society. They are among us. They have been with us for centuries. The signs have been there all along, and yet mankind has not heeded them. People allow themselves to suspend disbelief long enough to be scared by a motion picture or a well told ghost story, but there is always the sunlight to welcome them back into their ignorant waking slumber.

User summary:

Vampire Hunter$ OGL-Compatible Edition is adapted from the original edition to utilize the "Open Game License"(d20 Modern).

208485.description:
Something mysterious has happened in the town of Ravenwood. Professor Schauberger has been constructing a Time Machine in his observatory workshop, but he and the device have vanished.
The Mayor is offering a reward to anyone who can unravel the mystery by locating the missing pieces and the Professor. Players must search the mysterious locations of the town, while still running their business, shipping goods as merchants and traders. You never know who you will meet on your journey, or what you might find along the way. One thing is for sure however, somebody knows more than they are saying.

GAMEPLAY

There are six main character player cards, which may be dealt randomly or chosen by players at the start of the game. Once players have an identity, the cars are re-shuffled and one card is drawn in secret, as the culprit, to be placed in a Time Capsule along with Professor Schauberger.

Each player is given a matching character mat to track their working hours, coin collection, resources and locations visited during the game. As each of the players are merchants in the town, they must still work for essential items, shipping their goods using several forms of transport available in the game.

There are 36 Mystery locations on the board which contain either a town character or mystery box. With two cards per location, there are 72 possible hiding places for the missing pieces of the Time Machine. Some of those shady characters may help or hinder your progress. Not all locations are accessible immediately, so players must gather supplies to reach those places.

The game is turn based, and relies upon a custom dice to determine the players action during their turn, which are to work, trade or search. The winner is the player who contributes the most toward solving the mystery by adding the total number of locations searched, hours worked, resources collected and Time Machine components recovered, along with matching reward coins. The winner gets to assemble the Time Machine miniature and rescue the Professor, as well as earning the full reward. However, there is still the mystery of who the culprit actually is, which may change everything.

208490.name: Benefactor
208490.description:
Benefactor is a mix between a puzzle game and a platform game. It has a similar concept to Psygnosis's earlier, very successful Lemmings series of games, but also adds its own ideas.

In Benefactor, the player plays a character called Ben E. Factor, who has resigned from the military to become an overall all-around good guy. Factor's mission is to save a group of "Merry Men", who have been kidnapped from their home planet and imprisoned over 60 levels.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benefactor_(video_game),"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

208491.name: Hellboy: Dogs of the Night
208491.description:
Hellboy: Dogs of the Night is a 2000 American video game for the PC, developed by Cryo Studios. It was ported to the PlayStation titled Hellboy: Asylum Seeker (also the title for the PC re-release), developed by Hoplite Research and released in 2004.

The Hellboy game is based on Dark Horse Comics' science fiction comic book series Hellboy, written and drawn by Mike Mignola.

Commercially, the game was a flop. Having spent four years in development, the graphics and game play were quite dated, and at the time of its release, Hellboy was still a mostly unknown independent comic book series, especially outside the United States. Other factors contributed to the game's commercial failure, as well: the PC version had numerous bugs, the PlayStation version was graphically inferior to most others at the time, and the control of both games was considered abysmal at best.

Both Cryo Studios and Cryo Interactive went out of business shortly after Hellboy's PC release.

The PC version has a score of 11.50% at GameRankings.
Source: Wikipedia, "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellboy:_Dogs_of_the_Night," available under the CC-BY-SA License.
